subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... It s not a matter of finding a letter , so much as QS failing to make a distinction.  Many people living in and near New York City, for example, split the
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> True, QS with the wrong implementation cannot. But QS treated
> phonemically can: I do not believe there has ever been a QS user who
> tried to find a letter for a sound and failed.

It's not a matter of "finding a letter", so much as QS failing to
make a distinction. Many people living in and near New York City,
for example, split the TRAP lexical set into two different sets:
"can" (noun) and "halve" belong to one, "can" (verb) and "have"
belong to the other. Other words in the first set are "man", "bad"
and "ham"; in the second set, "hang", "pal", "lap", and "bat".

Now this difference is as salient to the people who make them
as the "cot" vs. "caught" distinction is to me, or the "sit" vs.
"seat" distinction is to most anglophones. But QS cannot represent
it, having only the one letter #30 At.

> 1. do not use letters for sounds not found in your accent.

I'm in favor of this in the following form:

1a. If two lexical sets are merged in your accent, use
either letter corresponding to that set;

1b. If some lexical sets are partly merged in your accent,
write the anomalous words as if they belonged to the
lexical set of the majority.

> 2. follow a complex set of rules to simulate Upper Class British
> English.

That would be unreasonable, and constitutes a caricature of my position.

> >Au contraire. Hundreds of thousands of words are affected.
>
> I'm sure you have a basis for this figure even though it so very
> strongly resembles a complete guess.

Every word that contains any of the short English vowels ("pat", "pet",
"pit", "pot", "putt", "foot") is changed by the vowel shift.

> show us an Australian and Non-Australian version of the same text side
> by side as I have done with US vs RP here:
> http://quickscript.tonygrahn.com/spellcomparison.html

I am a very non-visual person, and can't read JQS easily; SQS is
completely out of the question. Since you generated these programmatically,
can you post a Latin-alphabet representation, or QS letter numbers or names?
I could do something with that.

> Your proposed treatment of QS may get rid of some or many. Phonemic QS
> disposes of all TO irregularities.

I don't know whether you mean "phonemic" or "phonetic". I am arguing
for a phonemic treatment.

--
We call nothing profound cowan@...
that is not wittily expressed. John Cowan
--Northrop Frye (improved)
